ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Chinese history, culture, and advanced grammar structures.
Taking chinese to the next level and discussing a variety of cultural, political and art topics. We also cover a variety of chengyu and suyu
This class helped expand my vocabulary, particularly around the areas of arts, cuisine, and traditional Chinese idioms.

The courses taught me how to have conversations about various political and social issues as well as different forms of art and music in Chinese. I also improved my speaking and writing abilities for Chinese through the class assignments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are that the class is very engaging and that Wang Laoshi is invested in teaching us Chinese.

Strenghts: wang laoshi makes class fun and creates good teaching moments to make us remember expressions/differences between confusing terms. The course is extremely well structured and the homework helps fixate the content. It is an excellent course overall!

Weakness: Objectivelly I'd say none, but it sometimes depends on your classmates to be talkative for class to go well. I also thought the extra text that was added after we went through the textbook, although interesting, took time that would have been helpful for catchup/consolidating the massive amount of content we covered during the semester.

Strengths: small class size, regular assignments and check-ins, multiple tests instead of one big final. 

Weaknesses: could have spent more time in conversation.

The course material presented in class is highly engaging, allowing students to acquire a wealth of new vocabulary that finds application in daily intellectual conversations. However, one limitation of the course is that certain topics may not be covered in sufficient depth due to time constraints within the predetermined class schedule.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The chinese department at yale is phenomenal and Wang Laoshi is amazing. She makes content easy to memorize with her skits and really welcomes student engagement.
Yes! Language learning is all about practice, and this was a great way to keep improving my skills. Also, the Chinese department is just fantastic and has so many resources.
Definitely, if you want to continue practicing Chinese and improve your grip over the language.
